title: Jim Lambright
text:
James Ralph Lambright (April 26, 1942 – March 29, 2020) was an <a href="American%20football">American football</a> player and coach. He served as the head coach at the <a href="University%20of%20Washington">University of Washington</a> for six seasons, from <a href="1993%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1993</a> to <a href="1998%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1998</a>, compiling a record of Prior to becoming head coach, Lambright served as an assistant on the <a href="Washington%20Huskies%20football">Huskies</a> coaching staff for 24 seasons.
Early years.
Born and raised in <a href="Everett%2C%20Washington">Everett, Washington</a>, Lambright's father was a <a href="Commercial%20fishing">fisherman</a>. He played <a href="High%20school%20football">football</a> for head coach Jim Ennis at <a href="Everett%20High%20School%20%28Washington%29">Everett High School</a> and graduated in 1960. Lambright earned a <a href="athletic%20scholarship">scholarship</a> to the <a href="University%20of%20Washington">University of Washington</a> in <a href="Seattle">Seattle</a>, where he lettered as an undersized <a href="defensive%20end">defensive end</a> for head coach <a href="Jim%20Owens">Jim Owens</a>, earning all-conference and All-Coast honors as a senior for the <a href="Washington%20Huskies%20football">Huskies</a> in <a href="1964%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1964</a>.
Coaching career.
Following graduation, Lambright was an assistant coach at <a href="Fife%20High%20School">Fife High School</a> for a season in 1965 and then at <a href="Shoreline%20Community%20College">Shoreline Community College</a>. In <a href="1969%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1969</a>, Owens hired him as an assistant coach on the Huskies' staff. New head coach <a href="Don%20James%20%28American%20football%29">Don James</a> retained him in <a href="1975%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1975</a> and Lambright became the team's <a href="defensive%20coordinator">defensive coordinator</a> in <a href="1978%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1978</a>, and assistant head coach in <a href="1987%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1987</a>.
Lambright was an assistant coach for the Huskies for 24 seasons when he was elevated to head coach in late August <a href="1993%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1993</a>, following James' sudden resignation in protest of sanctions against the program from the <a href="National%20Collegiate%20Athletic%20Association">NCAA</a> and <a href="Pac-12%20Conference">Pac-10 Conference</a>, namely a two-year bowl ban. Lambright's initial contract as head coach was a four-year deal with a base salary of $150,000; he was earning $95,400 as James' chief assistant. He signed a contract extension in January 1998 that brought his compensation to over $500,000 annually. As the Huskies' defensive coordinator Lambright designed the team's "Purple Reign" defensive schemes.
After six seasons as head coach and three decades on staff, Lambright was relieved of his duties by <a href="athletic%20director">athletic director</a> Barbara Hedges in late December replaced by <a href="Rick%20Neuheisel">Rick Neuheisel</a> in January <a href="1999%20Washington%20Huskies%20football%20team">1999</a>. Lambright died from complications of dementia on March 29, 2020.
